DM11:19am

LLOY agrees to sell Irish residential mortgage book to BARC for £4bn generating c.25bps of CET1 capital: LLOY has this morning announced that it has agreed to sell its Irish residential mortgage portfolio to Barclays (BARC) for cash consideration of c.£4bn. The gross portfolio is c.£4.3bn in size and is predominantly performing in nature with just £0.3bn of the book impaired. In FY17, the assets generated a pre-tax loss of c.£40m. In overall terms, the sale will generate c.25bps of CET1 capital upon completion (expected in H218), with the transaction generating a pre-tax loss on sale of c.£110m which will be recognised in H118. Post the transaction LLOY Irish exposure will consist solely of a c.£4bn run-off portfolio, which is less than 1% of the group’s loans. In our view this transaction will be well received by the market this morning, bolstering LLOY CET1 position which stood at 14.4% (pre dividend accrual) at end-Q118.

PM11:19am

Trader Gordon likes it from the Lloyds side

11:19 am
PM11:19am

The Lloyds/HBOS foray into the Republic of Ireland more than a decade ago
was an unmitigated disaster, generating losses in excess of £12bn and (in
large part) necessitating the UK Government “bail-out” of January 2009. But
all’s well that ends well; Lloyds has now disposed of £4.3bn mortgage assets,
substantially all its residual Irish exposure. This gives a c.25bps uplift to CET1,
and underscores our expectation of an expanding buyback programme. BUY.

Mouselet still, *POLICE SHOULDN'T SHOOT FIRST* is kind of a rule. The reason we have things like the George Cross is to encourage that.
PM11:20am

Lloyds is currently in the early stages of its 2018 £1bn share buyback
programme. It has, thus far, repurchased c.379m shares at an average of c.66p
per share; £250m down, £750m to go. Looking ahead, we expect Lloyds to
increase its ordinary dividend from 3.05p in 2017 to 3.4-4.1p through 2018-
2020e, a prospective 2018-20e dividend yield of 5.1-6.2%. Additionally, we
continue to model a step-up in its share buyback programme from £1bn in 2018
to £1.5bn in 2019e and £2.0bn in 2020e, with CET1

14% throughout.

 Moreover, we forecast that Lloyds will deliver a statutory ROTE of

11% in

2018e, rising to 12.7-13.0% in 2019-20e. For context, we do not expect any
other FTSE100 bank to achieve an 11% ROTE before 2021e.
 Lloyds may not be an “exciting” story, but we see it as both resilient and
undervalued. It is our preferred FTSE100 play.

Carpetright has announced a fully underwritten proposed share issue to raise net proceeds of approximately £60.0m. The placing and open offer is being done at 28p, a c.16% discount to yesterday’s closing price of 33.25p. The £60m of net proceeds will be used as follows: £6.0m to cover the costs of the CVA, £12.5m to repay the first Meditor short term loan, £33.0m to fund future capex plans related to the revised business plan and the remaining £8.5m to fund the ongoing working capital needs of the business. There will be a General Meeting on 6th of June to approve the issue.

PM11:30am

We note the announcement from Carpetright that states it has a fully underwritten proposed share issue to raise net proceeds of approximately £60.0 million (£65.1 million gross) through the issue of 232,463,221 New Ordinary Shares by way of a Placing and Open Offer at a price of 28 pence per New Ordinary Share. The Issue Price represents a discount of 15.8 per cent. to the Closing Price of 33.25 pence per Ordinary Share on 17 May 2018. Carpetright will shortly send Shareholders a Prospectus in connection with the Placing and Open Offer. The Prospectus will contain a notice of a general meeting, to be held at 4 p.m. on 6 June 2018, to approve certain Resolutions necessary to implement the proposed Placing and Open Offer.

The proceeds of the equity raise will be used as follows: £6.0m to cover additional costs associated with implementing the CVA, £12.5m for the repayment of the interim loan entered into on 21 March 2018, £33.0m to fund the group’s capex plans as set out in the revised business plan and the remainder to fund ongoing working capital requirements.

The equity raise is subject to the passing of the resolutions which we hope is a formality and means the business will soon be at the start of it trading recovery journey. The new shares are due to be admitted on 8 June with the proceeds to be used to modernise the store estate and upgrade the digital platform. We now await any relevant company guidance in the preliminary results in June after which we should be able to start modelling how the restructure and recovery of the business could look in the years to come. In the meantime, we retain our HOLD stance.

DM11:34am

Q1 is a 1% product sales miss compensated by an externalisation beat to drive in-line total revenues, whilst core EBITA missed 13% on higher SG&A and lower OOI, and core EPS missed by 16% on higher financials. However all that is likely to be put in the shade by the product story with a strong mix driven by the new products

11:34 am
DM11:35am

Imfinzi beat by 39% along with beats for Tagrisso (4%), Lynparza (7%) and Fasenra (103%)

DM11:35am

Elsewhere there was further evidence of weakness in other primary care assets (respiratory, diabetes – including a notable miss for Bydureon) and LOE assets like Crestor. Our discussion with the company indicated the oncology beats are clean (e.g. no inventory movements behind the Imfinzi beat). Moreover, FY18 guidance is reiterated (for LSD product sales growth and core EPS of $3.30-50 plus now a LSD positive FX impact vs neutral prior) which thus implies a degree of cost/OOI-divestment phasing and limited mechanical impact on consensus estimates, given FY18 consensus is at $3.30 (BARC: $3.45).

DM11:36am

Thus despite the headline miss we actually regard this as a positive set of numbers (even acknowledging the weak operating cash flow on a large working capital swing…). On the R&D side KESTREL is pushed out to H2 (from Q2).

tangledodyssey The level of inventories in Laura Ashley are worrying. The competence of Management is questionable. If Khoo Kay Peng were to retire completely and give others a chance, that would be very positive. As it is, he controls over 40% of ALY.

11:39 am
DM11:39am

The company has reiterated its full-year guidance. It expects product sales to grow in the low single digits (at CER) and benefit from a low-single-digit currency tailwind. It still expects core EPS to be $3.30-3.50 at CER, but with a low-single-digit tailwind for EPS as well. This points to a full-year core EPS range of around $3.38-3.59, with a mid-point of $3.49. Consensus is a touch below the mid-point, at $3.43.

DM11:39am

Operating costs were $119m higher than expected, and this drove the majority of the core earnings miss. Within operating expenses the most notable miss was SG&A of $2,028m, which was $109m worse than expected. The company highlighted that this was due to investment in new product launches, but it also reflects a very low level of spend in the comparable quarter of 2017, which was below trend.

DM11:40am

AstraZeneca shares have performed well in recent months. Although guidance has been reiterated, the Q1 EPS miss may unsettle some investors and the shares may be a touch weak on these results.

11:44 am
PM11:45am

Exclusive deal with the US's biggest traditional grocer. We increase our
target price to 930p from 585p after Kroger announced plans for up to 20
customer fulfilment centres (CFCs) over the next three years. Like previous
transactions, this is an exclusive deal within the geography, albeit one with
annual turnover greater than $1T. We see Ocado's transition from a small, disruptive UK
grocery player to a global technology supplier as complete, with Ocado's
operational focus moving to the rollout of facilities on an international scale.
We believe further deals may still be possible given the modular, scalable,
and standardised characteristics of the technology, with other European
markets the most likely near-term targets. For details, please see our report
'Ocado: Automation is just the beginning'.

Soundbuy The Vatican has told nuns to limit their time on social media.........the mind boggles.....
PM11:45am

Primary risks relate to Ocado's ability to build, test and commission
multiple facilities concurrently. There is also market risk related to customer
adoption of online grocery in regions where penetration remains low. There is
no balance sheet risk given the £142m equity issue in February and the
£183m private placement of shares to Kroger as part of this transaction.
■ Valuation. Based on commentary from the CFO regarding the size of the
facilities for Kroger (similar to Ocado's smallest facility – CFC3 in Andover),
we now use a baseline valuation of 16p per facility. This valuation is driven
by our DCF model assuming: (i) a 5% operating fee and a 1% platform cost
(as a percentage of revenue); (ii) an 8-year ramp up period; and (iii) a 2-year
build phase. Our base case valuatoin now includes 30 of these facilities; 20
for Kroger, 3 for Sobey's, 3 for Casino, 1 for ICA and 3 further options

DM11:52am

Even before there is any fiscal shift following the formation of a new government, Italy has the second weakest fiscal position in the region. Although on the basis of current policy it is expected to have a primary surplus of 1.7% of GDP next year, debt is not expected to fall by enough to take it below 100% of GDP after 20 years. On the basis of these projections, Italian debt would stabilize with either a rise in average borrowing costs of just over a percentage point or a deterioration in the primary position of almost 1.5%-pts. Of course, politics could be a wild card for the growth, fiscal and financial outlook.

Lemmy Seem to recall an AV podcast about T-bills and whether they're a currency or not
Soundbuy Thought getting a plumber etc in Italy was nigh on impossible with the absence of cash.....
DM11:53am

Then we have UBS, asking what fiscal shock derails the Italian bond market

11:53 am
DM11:53am

We update our debt sustainability analysis for Italy. In the baseline scenario we continue to assume a terminal primary surplus of 2.5% of GDP; like before, we simulate Italy's future average cost of funding using current forward rates. One notable difference is a small upgrade in the macro assumptions owing to better recent growth performance.

DM11:53am

We then introduce two fiscal shock scenarios: a) A modest shock in the form of 1% of GDP increase in permanent spending, following which the primary surplus settles at 1% of GDP (Figure1). In this scenario growth is a little stronger in the first year before it settles at the long-term growth rate of 1%; and market yields rise by 30bps; b) A severe shock, in the form of a c.2% of GDP increase in fiscal spending, following which the primary balance settles at 0% of GDP (Figure1). In this scenario growth receives a larger boost in the first year and a more modest one in the second before it also settles at 1%; market yields rise by 100bps. (Note: we benchmark the size of fiscal shocks to preliminary estimates of the total cost of the fiscal measures proposed by the two parties as reported by Bloomberg, amounting to c. EUR 80bn or 4.4% of GDP).

Badger I'm still not entirely convinced Ocado's technology merits a valuation of over £5bn. Then again, I was surprised they elected the US president.

Miss Piggy EURUSD broadly unchanged for 24 hours
DM11:57am

The Eurozone's current account balance tends to be overlooked by the FX market but some attention is warranted. On a SA basis, the surplus stood at EUR32 billion in March after EUR36.8 billion in February. But if you thought this was an indication of a downward sloping profile for the series you'd be wrong. On a rolling 12M basis, the surplus was at EUR410 billion in March (highest on record). That’s approximately 4% of 2018 (estimated) Eurozone GDP, which is also the highest on record.

Lemmy we'll see in Italy, there's a good chance of fresh elections later this year, if they do form a government they might not have any time to actually implement anything

I just don't think pundits who believe equilibrium in EURUSD is in the $1.23-1.24 range are looking closely enough at the BoP. My view is that long run 'fair value' is probably higher than that. The OECD thinks so too by the way (its ‘fair value’ estimate of $1.3380 for EURUSD uses the goods & services GDP deflators).
